pullRequest.body:
Example:
```lean
inductive PList (Î± : Sort _) where
  | nil
  | cons (x : Î±) (xs : PList Î±)
  deriving Countable
```
This creates the instance
```lean
instance {Î± : Sort*} [Countable Î±] : Countable (PList Î±)
```

The deriving handler supports structures and all non-reflexive un-nested inductive types, including mutual inductive types.


---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

For details on the "pull request lifecycle" in mathlib, please see:
https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/index.html

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR
if it passes the continuous integration checks.
Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> Mathlib.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]

-->

### PR summary [b3193bafe3](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/18557/commits/b3193bafe36864d596fdb7580a087d75479a16d1)

<details><summary>

#### Import changes for modified files

</summary>

Dependency changes

| File | Base Count | Head Count | Change |
| --- | --- | --- | --- |
| Mathlib.Tactic | 2433 | 2437 | +4 (+0.16%) |


<details><summary>Import changes for all files</summary>

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|
| `Mathlib.Tactic`|4|
| `Mathlib.Tactic.DeriveCountable` (new file)|394|

</details>

</details>

---

<details><summary>

#### Declarations diff

</summary>

`+ I`
`+ Nested`
`+ PList`
`+ PreCantor'`
`+ Reflex`
`+ S`
`+ T.toNat`
`+ T.toNat_injective`
`+ T1`
`+ T2`
`+ instance (Î± : Type) [Countable Î±] : Countable (T Î±) := âŸ¨_, T.toNat_injective Î±âŸ©`
`+ mkCountableInstance`
`+ mkInjThms`
`+ mkToNatFuns`
`++ T`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

</details>

---

<details><summary>No changes to technical debt.</summary>

You can run this locally as
```
./scripts/technical-debt-metrics.sh pr_summary
```
* The `relative` value is the weighted *sum* of the differences with weight given by the *inverse* of the current value of the statistic.
* The `absolute` value is the `relative` value divided by the total sum of the inverses of the current values (i.e. the weighted *average* of the differences).
</details>

This is great! I can't really review meta code, but everything else looks fine.

Could this also be used to build an `Encodable` instance? It seems that with your approach, the precise constructor sequence building up a term should be readable by just calling the unpairing function on naturals repeatedly.

I'll leave writing an Encodable instance to someone else :-)  Edit: that someone else was me a few hours later: #18564

There's not much point in re-using the code for this, since it would want to use Encodable hypotheses rather than Countable. But, copy-and-pasting this module would be a good start. There are a couple big changes though: (1) it would need to generate three declarations rather than two (it needs that decoding function), and (2) rather than making an injectivity proof, it would need to make the left-inverse proof. I imagine that it's not too bad, but still there are details to work out.

Thanks!  Sorry for taking so long: this looks great!

bors r+

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded!

*And happy new year! ðŸŽ‰*


  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/12563250585/job/35024841089)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/12563250585/job/35024840850)
This looks very interesting!  I just gave the PR a first pass and flagged all the low level comments.  I will get back to look at the actual code later!
This looks very interesting!  I just gave the PR a first pass and flagged all the low level comments.  I will get back to look at the actual code later!
I'm not sure if this is particularly relevant, but the type is currently called `ONote` in Mathlib, even though I plan on renaming it soon.
I guess it's relevant in that I might not have added `'`, but the name doesn't matter for the tests. This one is testing that it works fine even when there's more than one induction hypothesis.

```suggestion
  (Countable.exists_injective_nat Î±).choose_spec
```

```suggestion
```
I prefer having some extra space before headings.

```suggestion

```
Is there a reason for not merging these module docs?
Yes, otherwise it will look like this module doc is explaining the heading, but it's marking a section of the implementation.

```suggestion
  | b (n : Nat) (x : Nat) (c : I x) : I (n + 1)
```

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat: `Countable` deriving handler
